Title: Comparative architectonic analysis of the human and the macaque frontal cortex

@BrainMaps_Delineation.Citation: "We studied a human brain that was sectioned in the coronal plane (36 micrometer in thickness) and stained with cresyl violet (Nissl stain) for cytoarchitectonic analysis and with the Loyez stain for myeloarchitecture. For the monkey (Macaca mulatta), we studied brains sectioned in the coronal plane (36 micrometer in thickness) and stained with cresyl violet (Nissl stain) for cytoarchitecture and the Heidenheim stain for myeloarchitecture."

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "Area 25 is located below the rostrum of the corpus callosum at the ventroposterior portion of the medial surface of the frontal lobe (...Barbas and Pandya, 1989)." (p. 41)
"As in the human brain, area 47/12 of the monkey can be subdivided into a lateral part, area 47/12(L), and an orbital part, area 47/12(O)." (pp. 35-36)
"As in the human brain, area 47/12 of the monkey can be subdivided into a lateral part, area 47/12(L), and an orbital part, area 47/12(O)." (pp. 35-36)
"Area 8...can be further subdivided into areas 8A and 8B." (pp. 23-24)
"Area 8...can be further subdivided into areas 8A and 8B." (pp. 23-24)
"We identify two subdivisions of area 8A: 8Ad (dorsal) and 8Av (ventral)." (p. 24)
"We identify two subdivisions of area 8A: 8Ad (dorsal) and 8Av (ventral)." (p. 24)
"[Area 44 is the] sulcal part of Vogt and Vogt's] areas 6a-alpha and 6b-alpha, [i.e. the] part that lies in the posterior bank of the lower ramus of the arcuate sulcus." (Table 2)
"[Area 44 is the] sulcal part of Vogt and Vogt's] areas 6a-alpha and 6b-alpha, [i.e. the] part that lies in the posterior bank of the lower ramus of the arcuate sulcus." (Table 2)
"[Area 45A is the] ventral-most part of [Brodmann's] area 9 and part of Brodmann's] area 10." (Table 2)
"[Area 45A is the] ventral-most part of [Brodmann's] area 9 and part of Brodmann's] area 10." (Table 2)

"Walker (1940) identified area 45 in the monkey brain immediately in front of the lower branch of the arcuate sulcus (Fig. 2C). We have observed this area that occupies the rostral bank of the lower limb of the arcuate sulcus, but we found that it extends quite further forward up to a small sulcus that lies below the mid-portion of the principal sulcus (Fig. 6A). This anterior extension, which had previously been included as part of areas 12 and 46, we designate as area 45A and the posterior part that lies in the rostral bank of the lower limb of the arcuate sulcus as area 45B." (p. 26) "[Area 45A is the] ventral-most part of [Walker's] area 46 and part of [Walker's] area 9." (Table 2)

"Walker (1940) identified area 45 in the monkey brain immediately in front of the lower branch of the arcuate sulcus (Fig. 2C). We have observed this area that occupies the rostral bank of the lower limb of the arcuate sulcus, but we found that it extends quite further forward up to a small sulcus that lies below the mid-portion of the principal sulcus (Fig. 6A). This anterior extension, which had previously been included as part of areas 12 and 46, we designate as area 45A and the posterior part that lies in the rostral bank of the lower limb of the arcuate sulcus as area 45B." (p. 26) "[Area 45A is the] ventral-most part of [Walker's] area 46 and part of [Walker's] area 9." (Table 2)
"Area 46 [is] part of [Brodmann's] area 9 and [covers the] dorsal-most part of [Brodmann's] area 10." (Table 2)
"Area 46 [is] part of [Brodmann's] area 9 and [covers the] dorsal-most part of [Brodmann's] area 10." (Table 2)
"[Area 8Ad is] part of [Vogt and Vogt's] area 9c and areas 8delta and 8alpha." (Table 2)
"[Area 8Ad is] part of [Vogt and Vogt's] area 9c and areas 8delta and 8alpha." (Table 2)
"[Area 8Ad is] part of [Vogt and Vogt's] area 9c and areas 8delta and 8alpha." (Table 2)

"In the monkey brain, Bonin and Bailey (1947) identified an area just behin the lower limb of the arcuate sulcus that they labelled FCBm. This part, however, is part of ventral area 6 as defined by Brodmann (1905)..."
"Area 11 [is] part of [Brodmann's] area 11." (Table 2)
"Area 25 is located below the rostrum of the corpus callosum at the ventroposterior portion of the medial surface of the frontal lobe (Vogt et al. 1987...)." (p. 41)
"Area 13 [is] part of [Brodmann's] area 11." (Table 2)
"Area 24 [is] part of [Brodmann's] area 24."
"Area 24 [is] part of [Walker's] area 24." (Table 2)

"Area 25 [is the] subcallosal part of [Walker's] area 24." (Table 2)
"Area 32 [is equal to the] dorsal area 25 [of Walker] above rostral sulcus." (Table 2)
"[Area 44 is the] sulcal part of [Brodmann's] ventral area 6, [i.e. the] part that lies in the posterior bank of the lower ramus of the arcuate sulcus." (Table 2)
"Area 45B [is the] ventral part of [Brodmann's] area 8." (Table 2)

"...area 46 in the monkey as defined by Walker (1940) is not homogeneous but exhibits a number of architectonic differences in its various parts. Only the cortex in the banks of the principal sulcus and the cortex surrounding the rostral part of this sulcus has cytoarchitectonic characteristics that resemble those of human area 46. We therefore restrict the use of the designation area 46 in the monkey to this cortex (Fig. 6A)." (p. 31) "Area 46 [is the] rostral part of [Walker's] area 46, particularly the part that lines the bak of the sulcus principalis." (Table 2)
"Area 47/12 [covers] most of [Brodmann's] area 10." (Table 2)

@InterMapRelations.Comments: There is a slight contradiction between Table 2, according to which PP94-32 and B09-32 are identical, and p. 55 that states: "In the monkey brain, Brodmann (1905) and Vogt et al. (1987) have identified area 32 as the cortical region lying between the cingulate and the rostral sulci in front of area 24. According to our observations, area 32 extends further caudally in the upper bank of the cingulate sulcus in the monkey brain." (Note: B05 did not recognize any area 32; this area was only  described in his later work, i.e. by B09.)

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "Walker (1940)...described an area that he labelled as area 12 at the most ventral part of the lateral frontal convexity extending, on the inferior surface, to the lateral orbital sulcus (Fig. 2C). As mentioned above, in the current cytoarchitectonic analysis, the dorsocaudal part of this area on the lateral convexity was considered to be part of area 45A (Fig. 6A). The remaining part of Walker's area 12, we consider to be comparable to cortical area 47/12 in the human brain...and is, accordingly, referred to as 47/12 to maintain consistency between the human and the monkey frontal cortex..." (pp. 35-36) "Area 47/12 [covers] most of [Walker's] area 12." (Table 2)
"[Area 8Ad is] part of [Brodmann's] area 8." (Table 2)
"[Area 8Ad is] part of [Walker's] area 8A." (Table 2)
"[Area 8Av is] part of [Brodmann's] area 8." (Table 2)
"[Area 8Av is] part of [Walker's] area 8A." (Table 2)
"Area 8B [covers the] caudodorsal part of area 9." (Table 2)
"Area 9 [is] part of [Brodmann's] area 9." (Table 2)
"Area 9/46d [is] part of [Brodmann's] area 9." (Table 2)
"Area 9/46d [is] part of [Vogt and Vogt's] area 9c." (Table 2)

"...the cortex that lies just above and below the caudal principal sulcus (and which Walker included in his area 46) has...features...similar to those of the specific part of Brodmann's area 9 that surrounds area 46 in the middle frontal gyrus. We have designated this area as 9/46...On the basis of minor architectonic differences, we distinguish between two subdivisions of 9/46, namely 9/46d, for the dorsal part, and 9/46v, for the ventral part." (pp. 31-32) "Area 9/46d [is the] dorsocaudal part of [Walker's] area 46." (Table 2)

"Walker (1940) identified area 45 in the monkey brain immediately in front of the lower branch of the arcuate sulcus (Fig. 2C). We have observed this area that occupies the rostral bank of the lower limb of the arcuate sulcus, but we found that it extends quite further forward up to a small sulcus that lies below the mid-portion of the principal sulcus (Fig. 6A). This anterior extension, which had previously been included as part of areas 12 and 46, we designate as area 45A and the posterior part that lies in the rostral bank of the lower limb of the arcuate sulcus as area 45B." (p. 26) "[Area] 45B [equals Walker's] area 45." (Table 2)
"Area 9/46v [is] part of [Brodmann's] area 9." (Table 2)

"...the cortex that lies just above and below the caudal principal sulcus (and which Walker included in his area 46) has...features...similar to those of the specific part of Brodmann's area 9 that surrounds area 46 in the middle frontal gyrus. We have designated this area as 9/46...On the basis of minor architectonic differences, we distinguish between two subdivisions of 9/46, namely 9/46d, for the dorsal part, and 9/46v, for the ventral part." (pp. 31-32) "Area 9/46v [is the] ventrocaudal part of [Walker's] area 46." (Table 2)

"In Brodmann's (1905) map of the monkey brain...area 9 oocupies a significant portion of the lateral prefrontal cortex, extending rostrally from area 8...No area 46 was identified...By contrast, Walker (1940) designated a large portion of the region labelled as area 9 by Brodmann...as area 46, limiting the designation area 9 only to the dorsal part of this region (Fig. 2C)."

"In Brodmann's (1905) map of the monkey brain...area 9 oocupies a significant portion of the lateral prefrontal cortex, extending rostrally from area 8...No area 46 was identified...By contrast, Walker (1940) designated a large portion of the region labelled as area 9 by Brodmann...as area 46, limiting the designation area 9 only to the dorsal part of this region (Fig. 2C)."

"As in the human brain, area 24 surrounds the rostral part of the corpus callosum. It extends dorsally to the lower bank of the cingulate sulcus (Fig. 24A-C). Its cytoarchitecture is very similar to that of area 24 in the human brain. It has a poorlydefined layer III. Layer III contains small to medium pyramidal neurons that are sparsely distributed. Layer IV cannot be discerned. ... As in the human brain, area 24 has been further subdivided into horizontally oriented subareas: 24a, 24b and 24c. Subdivisions 24a and 24b lie on the surface of the cingulate gyrus and 24c lies mostly in the lower bank of the cingulate sulcus (Vogt, Pandya and Rosene, 1987)."

"...we found that, in the dorsal part of the frontal lobe of the monkey, there is a distinct strip of cortex between area 6 posteriorly and area 9 anteriorly and extends medially as far as the cingulate sulcus. In agreement with Walker, we recognize this region as area 8B (Figs. 6A, B)."
"In the monkey brain, Brodmann (1905) and Vogt et al. (1987) have identified area 32 as the cortical region lying between the cingulate and the rostral sulci in front of area 24." (p. 55)
@InterMapRelations.Comments: B05 did not recognize any area 32; this area was only  described in his later work, i.e. by B09. Unfortunately, this confusion is often seen in the literature.

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "Although area 32 was identified by Brodmann (1905) in the monkey (Fig. 2A), Walker (1940) labelled this same area as 25 (Fig. 2C)." (p. 41)
@InterMapRelations.Comments: B05 did not identify any area 32. This area occured only in his later work (B09). Also, Fig. 2A does not show the map of B05, but of B09.

"As in the human brain, area 24 surrounds the rostral part of the corpus callosum. It extends dorsally to the lower bank of the cingulate sulcus (Fig. 24A-C). Its cytoarchitecture is very similar to that of area 24 in the human brain. It has a poorlydefined layer III. Layer III contains small to medium pyramidal neurons that are sparsely distributed. Layer IV cannot be discerned. ... As in the human brain, area 24 has been further subdivided into horizontally oriented subareas: 24a, 24b and 24c. Subdivisions 24a and 24b lie on the surface of the cingulate gyrus and 24c lies mostly in the lower bank of the cingulate sulcus (Vogt, Pandya and Rosene, 1987)."

"...we found that, in the dorsal part of the frontal lobe of the monkey, there is a distinct strip of cortex between area 6 posteriorly and area 9 anteriorly and extends medially as far as the cingulate sulcus. In agreement with Walker, we recognize this region as area 8B (Figs. 6A, B)."
"In the monkey brain, Brodmann (1905) and Vogt et al. (1987) have identified area 32 as the cortical region lying between the cingulate and the rostral sulci in front of area 24." (p. 55)

publication.title: Comparative architectonic analysis of the human and the macaque frontal cortex
